query: MMP for Calabi-Yau fibrations
paper: Moduli of surfaces fibered in log Calabi-Yau pairs

The proper transform of the boundary remains ample over each step, and relative dimension one is preserved. For morphism steps, weak canonical models are obtained, and KSBA-stable limits become independent of small perturbations.
body-and-summary-v1: The minimal model program for log Calabi-Yau fibrations establishes that running MMP on the base generalized pair induces compatible birational contractions on the total space, preserving ampleness and relative dimension properties, with applications to KSBA-stable limits in moduli theory.

paper: Root stack valuative criterion for good moduli spaces

body-and-summary-v1: For reductive groups that are special or have tame Weyl groups, cohomology classes trivial over the fraction field become trivial on root stacks. This implies triviality over the residue field when the class vanishes over the generic point. The result supports applications in parahoric extension of torsors and rational points on stacks. It provides a root stack valuative criterion for reductive group gerbes.

query: Reductive group over an complete DVR admits a maximal torus

body-and-summary-v1: A gerbe over an algebraic stack with an fppf cover that trivializes to a reductive group gerbe admits a reductive group form with matching band. body-and-summary-v1: The set of points in a good moduli space where the fiber is isomorphic to the point is open when the moduli space is separated.

query: Deligne-Mumford open in a stack with a good moduli space agrees with the semistable locus of a line bundle
paper: Stable maps to quotient stacks with a properly stable point

Let L be a line bundle on X which, when restricted to X', descends to a line bundle L_X' on X' that is ample over X. If the complement of X' in X has codimension at least 2 and X is normal, then X' equals the semistable locus of L over X.
body-and-summary-v1: An algebraic stack with a good moduli space and a dense open substack having a projective good moduli space equals the semistable locus when the complement has codimension at least 2 and the stack is normal. This result helps compactify moduli stacks of maps to quotient stacks and applies to various geometric contexts including fibered log-Calabi-Yau pairs and GIT compactifications.

When n > 4, the first Ext group vanishes and [Z/G] has only trivial infinitesimal deformations. When n = 4, the first Ext group is one-dimensional and [Z/G] admits a unique formal smoothing direction. The group acts by scaling x, y, and z by xi squared.
body-and-summary-v1: For even n, group action on quadratic cone shows trivial deformations when n>4, unique smoothing when n=4, relating to elliptic surface moduli.

body-and-summary-v1: A smooth tame Deligne-Mumford stack can be uniquely reconstructed from its coarse moduli space when both the scheme and its root stack have finite tame quotient singularities, extending ramification data from a dense open subscheme with codimension at least 2 complement.

This construction works for tame separated Deligne-Mumford stacks.
body-and-summary-v1: A smooth Deligne-Mumford stack containing a weighted projective bundle divisor with specific normal bundle conditions is a weighted blow-up. The stack contracts to a smooth target where the divisor becomes the exceptional locus. The original stack can be reconstructed as a weighted blow-up along the center. query: Contracting elliptic tails is a weighted blow-up

The moduli space M1n is realized as a weighted blow up of M1n* along the center M0,n+1. This construction provides a contraction diagram relating these moduli spaces. The embedding and blow up structure connects different genus moduli spaces systematically.
body-and-summary-v1: The moduli stack of stable n-pointed genus one curves is a weighted blow-up of a smooth Deligne-Mumford stack along the moduli stack of stable rational curves with n+1 marked points. This construction works over characteristic zero fields for n at least 2. The blow-up center is embedded as a closed substack, and the exceptional divisor corresponds to curves with elliptic tails. This provides a geometric relationship between moduli spaces of curves of different genera.

query: Covers of P1 ramified at two points

The map is equivalent to raising homogeneous coordinates to the nth power. This characterizes all such morphisms with exactly two branch points. The curve C is necessarily rational.
body-and-summary-v1: A generically etale morphism from a curve to the projective line ramified only over two points must be isomorphic to the projective line itself, with the map taking the form of coordinate raising to a power.

query: Stack where every point’s closure contains a single closed point
paper: Existence of good moduli spaces for algebraic stacks

The result ensures closure properties in such geometric settings. It aids in understanding point closures in reductive stacks.
body-and-summary-v1: For a locally reductive algebraic stack locally of finite type over a field, if the stack is Theta-reductive then every k-point closure contains exactly one closed point. This result provides conditions for stacks with positive dimensional automorphism groups to have good moduli spaces. It generalizes the Keel-Mori theorem to moduli problems with automorphisms. The theorem gives criteria for separated or proper moduli spaces in applications like semistable G-bundles on curves.

query: Degeneration to the polystable point in an orbit is realized by a family over Theta
paper: Existence of good moduli spaces for algebraic stacks

This applies to stacks locally of finite type. The result connects specialization phenomena to geometric morphisms. It provides a concrete realization of specialization sequences in algebraic geometry.
body-and-summary-v1: For locally reductive algebraic stacks over algebraically closed fields, every specialization from a point to a closed point can be realized by a morphism from the affine line with doubled origin. This result generalizes the Keel-Mori theorem to moduli problems with positive dimensional automorphism groups. It provides criteria for when algebraic stacks admit separated or proper good moduli spaces. The theorem applies to constructing moduli spaces for semistable G-bundles on curves and objects in abelian categories.

query: An algebraic stack is locally the quotient of the normal bundle by the stabilizer group
paper: A Luna ‘etale slice theorem for algebraic stacks

The construction yields an unramified equivariant morphism whose induced map on quotient stacks is etale. When a good GIT quotient exists, the local model connects to the global quotient via etale maps. For smooth points, the normal space to the orbit provides a cartesian diagram relating local and global structures.
body-and-summary-v1: For algebraic spaces with group actions, near points with linearly reductive stabilizers, there exists an equivariant local quotient stack structure. The construction yields an unramified G_x-equivariant morphism to an affine scheme whose induced map to the quotient stack is etale. When a good GIT quotient exists, the induced quotient map is also etale. In smooth cases, the construction relates to the normal space to the orbit with cartesian diagrams.

query: Every good moduli space gerbe factors as a smooth gerbe and a tame gerbe

query: Projectivity criteria for good moduli spaces
paper: Proper splittings and projectivity for good moduli spaces
body-only-v1: A good moduli space with proper base and a surjection from a finite rank vector bundle to a locally free sheaf yields an ample line bundle under certain positivity conditions, ensuring projectivity. The conditions include descent of a tensor power of the determinant, finiteness of closed points in fibers, and weak semi-positivity with linearly reductive structure group or related polynomial representations. Alternatively, for curves mapping to the polystable locus, the pullback decomposes into a degree zero twist of a bundle of the specified form. This ampleness result implies the base is projective.
body-and-summary-v1: Kollar's ampleness lemma generalizes to good moduli spaces: A line bundle descending from a determinant of a quotient is ample under conditions including finite closed points in fibers and weak semi-positivity, implying projectivity of the moduli space.

query: Algorithm for computing the valuative criterion cyclotomic stacks
paper: Height moduli on cyclotomic stacks and counting elliptic curves over function fields

body-and-summary-v1: The universal tuning stack for a rational map from a curve to weighted projective space is a root stack determined by minimal orders of vanishing. A unique minimal weighted linear series induces the map, with stacky height equal to its degree. Local contributions at indeterminacy points are fractions determined by minimal vanishing data. This framework connects rational points on stacks with twisted maps and weighted linear series.

When g is congruent to 3 modulo 9, the Picard group is isomorphic to the integers direct sum Z/9Z.

query: (Integral) intersection theory of H_{g,1}
paper: The Integral Chow Ring of the Stack of 1-Pointed Hyperelliptic Curves
body-only-v1: The Chow ring of the moduli space of hyperelliptic curves with one marked point is generated by two degree 1 elements t1 and t2. For even genus, the pullback from the unmarked moduli space sends c1 to t1+t2 and c2 to t1t2. For odd genus, the pullback sends tau to t1, c2 to -t2 squared, and c3 to zero. The ideal of relations for the marked moduli space is generated by the image of the relations from the unmarked moduli space.
body-and-summary-v1: The integral Chow ring of the stack of 1-pointed hyperelliptic curves is generated by two degree-1 elements t1 and t2. The pullback from the Chow ring of unpointed hyperelliptic curves depends on whether g is even or odd. For even g, c1 maps to t1+t2 and c2 maps to t1t2. For odd g, tau maps to t1, c2 maps to -t2 squared, and c3 maps to 0, with relations inherited from the unpointed case.

query: Relation between derived Azumaya algebras and Gm-gerbes

Conversely, it sends a gerbe G to the category of quasi-coherent sheaves on G with identity action in non-negative degrees. This correspondence preserves the symmetric monoidal structures on both sides.
body-and-summary-v1: For a qcqs scheme X over a field k, there exists a symmetric monoidal equivalence between the derived Brauer group Br(X) and the gerbe space Ger_Gm(X). The equivalence is given by the functor Phi mapping M to connective trivializations Triv_>=0(M) and the inverse functor Psi mapping G to connective quasi-coherent sheaves QCoh_id(G)_>=0.

The result represents the culmination of a four-paper series computing the Chow ring of M3 bar.

query: Invariance for derived structure of good moduli space

When a derived stack has a good moduli space, its classical truncation inherits one. Conversely, if the classical truncation has a good moduli space, the derived stack can be equipped with a compatible one. This establishes equivalence between derived and classical good moduli space existence.

query: Universality of derived good moduli space
paper: Good Moduli Spaces for Derived Algebraic Geometry

This fits into a Cartesian square where the good moduli space U//G_x maps etalely to Y. The point u in U is fixed by G_x and maps to x via Phi. This provides a local etale description of the stack near closed points.

body-and-summary-v1: The moduli space of stable 2-pointed genus 1 curves over a scheme where 6 is invertible is isomorphic to a weighted blow-up of a weighted projective stack. Specifically, the blow-up of the weighted projective stack with weights 2, 3, and 4 at a section with weights 4 and 6 yields the moduli space. This explicit geometric description facilitates computations of Brauer groups and Chow rings for these moduli spaces. The construction works over any base scheme where 6 is invertible.

query: The moduli space of genus one curves with two marked points is a blow-up
paper: Moduli of genus one curves with two marked points as a weighted blow-up
body-only-v1: Over a scheme where 6 is invertible, the weighted projective stack with weights 2, 3, 4 has a section. The weighted blow-up of this stack at the section with weights 4 and 6 yields the moduli stack of 2-pointed stable curves of genus 1. This construction provides an explicit geometric model for the moduli space. The result holds over the base scheme S.

Specifically, the blow-up of the weighted projective stack with weights 2, 3, and 4 at a section with weights 4 and 6 yields the moduli space. This explicit geometric description facilitates computations of Brauer groups and Chow rings for these moduli spaces. The construction works over any base scheme where 6 is invertible.
